<|endoftext|>/*
Check if in given vector of numbers, are any two numbers closer to each other than
given threshold.
>>> receive_close_elements({1.0, 2.0, 3.0}, 0.5)
false
>>> receive_close_elements({1.0, 2.8, 3.0, 4.0, 5.0, 2.0}, 0.3)
true
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<vector>
#include<math.h>
using namespace std;
bool receive_close_elements(vector<float> numbers, float threshold){
    float sum = 0;
    for(int i = 0; i < numbers.size(); i++){
        sum += numbers[i];
    }
    float average = sum / numbers.size();
    for(int i = 0; i < numbers.size(); i++){
        if(numbers[i] > average){
            return true;
        }
    }
    return false;
}

Given a vector of integers, sort the integers that are between 1 and 9 inclusive,
reverse the resulting vector, and then replace each digit by its corresponding name from
"One", "Two", "Three", "Four", "Five", "Six", "Seven", "Eight", "Nine".

For example:
  arr = {2, 1, 1, 4, 5, 8, 2, 3}   
        -> sort arr -> {1, 1, 2, 2, 3, 4, 5, 8} 
        -> reverse arr -> {8, 5, 4, 3, 2, 2, 1, 1}
  return {"Eight", "Five", "Four", "Three", "Two", "Two", "One", "One"}

  If the vector is empty, return an empty vector:
  arr = {}
  return {}

  If the vector has any strange number ignore it:
  arr = {1, -1, 55} 
        -> sort arr -> {-1, 1, 55}
        -> reverse arr -> {55, 1, -1}
  return = {"One"}
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<vector>
#include<string>
#include<map>
#include<algorithm>
using namespace std;
vector<string> by_duration(vector<int> arr){
    vector<string> ret;
    map<int, string> m;
    for(int i=0;i<arr.size();i++){
        m[arr[i]] = to_string(i);
    }
    for(auto it=m.begin();it!=m.end();it++){
        string s = it->second;
        for(int i=0;i<s.size();i++){
            string temp = s.substr(0,i) + it->second + s.substr(i+1);
            ret.push_back(temp);
        }
    }
    return ret;
}

number of ones in their binary representation in ascending order.

>>> sort_vector({1, 5, 2, 3, 4}) == {1, 2, 3, 4, 5}
>>> sort_vector({-2, -3, -4, -5, -6}) == {-6, -5, -4, -3, -2}

#include<stdio.h>

#include<vector>
#include<algorithm>

vector<int> sort_array(vector<int> arr){
    sort(arr.begin(), arr.end(), [](int a, int b){
        return count_ones(a) < count_ones(b);
    });
    return arr;
}
vector<int> sort_vector(vector<int> arr){
    sort(arr.begin(), arr.end(), [](int a, int b){
        return a < b;
    });
    return arr;
}

The Collatz conjecture is a conjecture in mathematics that concerns a sequence defined as follows: start with any positive integer n. Then each term is obtained from the previous term as follows: if the previous term is even, the next term is one half of the previous term. If the previous term is odd, the next term is 3 times the previous term plus 1. The conjecture is that no matter what value of n, the sequence will always reach 1. Note: 1. Collatz(1) is {1}. 2. returned vector sorted in increasing order. Return vector of all prefixes from shortest to longest of the input string
>>> all_prefix("abc")
{"a", "ab", "abc"}
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<vector>
#include<string>
using namespace std;
vector<string> all_prefix(string str){
    vector<string> prefixes;
    string prefix;
    for(int i=0;i<str.size();i++){
        prefix = str.substr(0,i);
        prefixes.push_back(prefix);
    }
    return prefixes;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Write a function that accepts a vector of strings as a parameter,
deletes the strings that have odd lengths from it,
and returns the resulted vector with a sorted order,
The vector is always a vector of strings and never a vector of numbers,
and it may contain duplicates.
The order of the vector should be ascending by length of each word, and you
should return the vector sorted by that rule.
If two words have the same length, sort the vector alphabetically.
The function should return a vector of strings in sorted order.
You may assume that all words will have the same length.
For example:
assert vector_sort({"aa", "a", "aaa"}) => {"aa"}
assert vector_sort({"ab", "a", "aaa", "cd"}) => {"ab", "cd"}
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<vector>
#include<string>
#include<algorithm>
using namespace std;
vector<string> screen_tilt_sum(vector<string> lst){
    sort(lst.begin(), lst.end());
    vector<string> res;
    for(int i = 0; i < lst.size(); i++){
        if(lst[i].length() % 2!= 0){
            res.push_back(lst[i]);
        }
    }
    sort(res.begin(), res.end());
    return res;
}

<|endoftext|>#include<stdio.h>
#include<math.h>
#include<vector>
using namespace std;
double poly(vector<double> xs, double x){
    /* 
    Evaluates polynomial with coefficients xs at point x. return xs[0] + xs[1] * x + xs[1] * x^2 +.... xs[n] * x^n 
    */
    double sum=0;
    int i;
    for (i=0;i<xs.size();i++)
    {
        sum+=xs[i]*pow(x,i);
    }
    return sum;
}

double find_zero(vector<double> xs){
    /*
    xs are coefficients of a polynomial. find_zero find x such that poly(x) = 0. find_zero returns only only zero point, even if there are many. 
    Moreover, find_zero only takes list xs having even number of coefficients and largest non zero coefficient as it guarantees a solution.
    >>> round(find_zero([1, 2]), 2) #f(x) = 1 + 2x 
    -0.5 
    >>> round(find_zero([-6, 11, -6, 1]), 2) # (x - 1) * (x - 2) * (x - 3) = -6 + 11x - 6x^2 + x^3 
    1.0
    */
    int i;
    double x=0, y=0;
    for (i=0;i<xs.size();i++){
        x=xs[i];
        if (poly(xs)==0)
        {
            y=x;
            break;
        }
    }
    return y;
}

The frequency of an integer is the number of times it appears in the vector.

    research({4, 1, 2, 2, 3, 1}) == 2
    research({1, 2, 2, 3, 3, 3, 4, 4, 4}) == 3

        if(lst[i]>max){
            max=lst[i];
        }
        if(lst[i]==max){
            count++;
        }

}

#include<vector>
#include<algorithm>

}
vector<int> strange_sort_vector(vector<int> lst){
    vector<int> lst2;
    for(int i = 0; i < lst.size(); i++){
        for(int j = i; j < lst.size(); j++){
            if(lst[i] > lst[j]){
                int temp = lst[i];
                lst[i] = lst[j];
                lst[j] = temp;
            }
        }
    }
    for(int i = 0; i < lst.size(); i++){
        lst2.push_back(lst[i]);
    }
    return lst2;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
You are given a 2 dimensional data, as a nested vectors,
which is similar to matrix, however, unlike matrices,
each row may contain a different number of columns.
Given lst, and integer x, find integers x in the vector,
and return vector of vectors, {{x1, y1}, {x2, y2}...} such that
each vector is a coordinate - {row, columns}, starting with 0.
Sort coordinates initially by rows in ascending order.
Also, sort coordinates of the row by columns in descending order.

Examples:
catch_row({
  {1,2,3,4,5,6},
  {1,2,3,4,1,6},
  {1,2,3,4,5,1}
}, 1) == {{0, 0}, {1, 4}, {1, 0}, {2, 5}, {2, 0}}
catch_row({}, 1) == {}
catch_row({{}, {1}, {1, 2, 3}}, 3) == {{2, 2}}
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<vector>
using namespace std;
vector<vector<int>> catch_row(vector<vector<int>> lst, int x){
    vector<vector<int>> res;
    vector<int> row;
    vector<int> col;
    for(int i = 0; i < lst.size(); i++){
        row.push_back(i);
    }
    for(int i = 0; i < lst.size(); i++){
        col.push_back(i);
    }
    sort(row.begin(), row.end());
    sort(col.begin(), col.end());
    for(int i = 0; i < row.size(); i++){
        for(int j = 0; j < col.size(); j++){
            if(lst[row[i]][col[j]] == x){
                res.push_back({row[i], col[j]});
            }
        }
    }
    return res;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Create a function encrypt that takes a string as an argument and
returns a string encrypted with the alphabet being rotated. 
The alphabet should be rotated in a manner such that the letters 
shift down by two multiplied to two places.
For example:
encrypt("hi") returns "lm"
encrypt("asdfghjkl") returns "ewhjklnop"
encrypt("gf") returns "kj"
encrypt("et") returns "ix"
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<string>
using namespace std;
string encrypt(string s){
    string temp;
    for(int i=0;i<s.length();i++){
        temp[i]=s[i];
    }
    for(int i=0;i<s.length();i++){
        temp[i]=temp[i+1];
    }
    return temp;
}

decrypt("kj") returns "gf"
decrypt("ix") returns "et"
*/
#include<stdio.h>

string decrypt(string s){
    string temp;
    for(int i=0;i<s.length();i++){
        temp[i]=s[i];
    }
    for(int i=0;i<s.length();i++){
        temp[i]=temp[i-1];
    }

}
